message_text:
Paper Title: Human-Agent Teamwork and Adjustable Autonomy in Practice Paper Abstract: This paper outlines a preliminary perspective on teamwork and adjustable autonomy in groups involving a mix of humans and autonomous agents. Unlike other approaches to agent teamwork, a humancentered perspective to human-agent interaction is used. The paper describes how we are integrating the Brahms and KAoS agent frameworks in order to model and simulate realistic work situations in space and to support the design of robotic and software agents for human-agent teamwork.
Presented at the 7th International Symposium on Artificial Intelligence, Robotics, and Automation in Space: i-SAIRAS 2003, Nara, Japan, May 19-23, 2003 "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Web search results for query: "adjustable autonomy"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomy"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Autonomous administrative division - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Service autonomy principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_Autonomy_Principle"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomist Marxism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomism"},{"title":"Autonomous things - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_things"}]

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about adjustable autonomy. The most pertinent result discusses this concept in the context of human-robot interaction:

Adjustable autonomy refers to accommodating varying degrees of autonomy, interaction patterns, and capabilities of different agents (both human and robotic). This concept is part of a broader approach called adaptive collaborative control.

Adaptive collaborative control is a decision-making approach that enables humans and robots to work together as partners rather than in traditional master-slave relationships. Unlike conventional robotic systems where humans directly control every action, adaptive collaborative control allows autonomous agents (robots) and human operators to collaborate as peers, sharing decision-making responsibilities to accomplish common goals.

In this framework, constraints operate primarily at the strategic level, governing high-level goals and tasks as defined by human operators, while lower-level tactical decisions remain adaptive and flexible, accommodating varying degrees of autonomy.

The approach also includes robots querying humans to receive input on decisions that affect their tasks or when presented with safety-related issues, enabling dynamic adjustment of how much autonomy the system exercises based on the situation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomy"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Autonomous administrative division - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Service autonomy principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_Autonomy_Principle"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomist Marxism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomism"},{"title":"Autonomous things - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_things"}]

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about adjustable autonomy. The most pertinent result discusses this concept in the context of human-robot interaction:

Adjustable autonomy refers to accommodating varying degrees of autonomy, interaction patterns, and capabilities of different agents (both human and robotic). This concept is part of a broader approach called adaptive collaborative control.

Adaptive collaborative control is a decision-making approach that enables humans and robots to work together as partners rather than in traditional master-slave relationships. Unlike conventional robotic systems where humans directly control every action, adaptive collaborative control allows autonomous agents (robots) and human operators to collaborate as peers, sharing decision-making responsibilities to accomplish common goals.

In this framework, constraints operate primarily at the strategic level, governing high-level goals and tasks as defined by human operators, while lower-level tactical decisions remain adaptive and flexible, accommodating varying degrees of autonomy.

The approach also includes robots querying humans to receive input on decisions that affect their tasks or when presented with safety-related issues, enabling dynamic adjustment of how much autonomy the system exercises based on the situation.

Here are the search results for "multi-agent system simulation":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Many MAS are implemented in computer simulations, stepping the system through discrete "time steps".

## Agent-Based Models

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## Key Characteristics

Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Applications

Multi-agent Systems Artificial Intelligence are used for simulating societies in the fields of climate, energy, epidemiology, conflict management, and child abuse. Specific real-world examples include Waymo, which has created a multi-agent simulation environment Carcraft to test algorithms for self-driving cars.

## Software Tools

Several platforms exist for developing multi-agent simulations:

- MASON is a multi-agent simulation environment developed in Java that was first released in 2003.
- GAMA (GIS Agent-based Modeling Architecture) is a simulation platform with a complete modelling and simulation integrated development environment for writing and experimenting spatially explicit agent-based models.

I found comprehensive information about robotic agent software. Here's an overview:

## Definition and Types

Robot software is the set of coded commands or instructions that tell a mechanical device and electronic system, known together as a robot, what tasks to perform.(no content)The word robot can refer to both physical robots and virtual software agents, but the latter are usually referred to as bots.

## Robotic Process Automation (RPA)

Robotic process automation (RPA) is a form of business process automation that is based on software robots (bots) or artificial intelligence (AI) agents.(no content)The robot uses keyboard and mouse controls to take actions and execute automations, with actions normally taking place in a virtual environment.

## Operating Systems and Frameworks

Robot Operating System (ROS) is an open-source software set of programs being developed at Stanford University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the Technical University of Munich, Germany, among others, and provides ways to program a robot's navigation and limbs regardless of the specific hardware involved.

## Autonomous Agents

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An agent can be anything that perceives its environment using sensors and acts upon it using actuators, such as a robot with cameras and wheels, or a software program that reads data and makes recommendations.

## Recent Developments

Companies like UiPath develop agentic automation software that combines robots, AI agents and people to automate workflows and processes.

Web search results for query: "human-computer interaction cooperation"

Links: [{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Outline of human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Modality (human–computer interaction) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modality_(human–computer_interaction)"},{"title":"Multimodal interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_interaction"},{"title":"Category:Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Human-centered computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-centered_computing"},{"title":"University of Maryland Human–Computer Interaction Lab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Maryland_Human_-_Computer_Interaction_Lab"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93robot_collaboration"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Human–Computer Interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Human–Computer_Interaction"},{"title":"Human-AI interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-AI_interaction"}]

I've completed a web search for "human-computer interaction cooperation." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Human-Computer Interaction Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems, with research covering the design and use of computer technology focused on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Cooperation and Collaboration in HCI

The search results reveal several aspects of cooperation within human-computer interaction:

**Modern Design Approaches**: Present-day models center on steady input and discussion between clients, creators, and specialists and push for technical systems to be folded with the sorts of experiences clients need to have.

**Human-Robot Collaboration**: Collaboration is defined as a special type of coordinated activity where two or more agents work jointly with each other, typically involving shared plans, shared norms and mutually beneficial interactions, though collaboration differs from cooperation as it involves a shared goal and joint action where the success of both parties depend on each other.

**The Human Complementary Approach**: The human complementary approach seeks to improve human-computer interaction by making the computer a more intelligent partner that complements and collaborates with humans, with researchers inventing interaction paradigms that divide responsibility between human users and computer systems by assigning distinct roles that exploit the strengths and overcome the weaknesses of both partners.

**Human-AI Collaboration**: Human-AI collaboration occurs when the human and AI supervise the task on the same level and extent to achieve the same goal, with some collaboration occurring in the form of augmenting human capability.

Human-computer interaction cooperation emphasizes designing systems where humans and computers work together effectively, leveraging the strengths of each.

Human-computer interaction cooperation emphasizes designing systems where humans and computers work together effectively, leveraging the strengths of each.

## Human-Computer Interaction Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems, with research covering the design and use of computer technology focused on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Cooperation and Collaboration in HCI

The search results reveal several aspects of cooperation within human-computer interaction:

**Modern Design Approaches**: Present-day models center on steady input and discussion between clients, creators, and specialists and push for technical systems to be folded with the sorts of experiences clients need to have.

**Human-Robot Collaboration**: Collaboration is defined as a special type of coordinated activity where two or more agents work jointly with each other, typically involving shared plans, shared norms and mutually beneficial interactions, though collaboration differs from cooperation as it involves a shared goal and joint action where the success of both parties depend on each other.

**The Human Complementary Approach**: The human complementary approach seeks to improve human-computer interaction by making the computer a more intelligent partner that complements and collaborates with humans, with researchers inventing interaction paradigms that divide responsibility between human users and computer systems by assigning distinct roles that exploit the strengths and overcome the weaknesses of both partners.

**Human-AI Collaboration**: Human-AI collaboration occurs when the human and AI supervise the task on the same level and extent to achieve the same goal, with some collaboration occurring in the form of augmenting human capability.

Human-computer interaction cooperation emphasizes designing systems where humans and computers work together effectively, leveraging the strengths of each.

I've performed a web search on "autonomous agent robotics" and found comprehensive information across several topics. Here are the key findings:

## Autonomous Agents and Robots

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control, with historic examples including space probes and modern examples including self-driving vacuums and cars.(no content)An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence system that can perform complex tasks independently. More specifically, an autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Key Capabilities

Robots tend to possess some or all of the following abilities and functions: accept electronic programming, process data or physical perceptions electronically, operate autonomously to some degree, move around, operate physical parts of itself or physical processes, sense and manipulate their environment, and exhibit intelligent behavior.

## Navigation and Movement

Autonomous mobile robots (AMR) are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.(no content)Current commercial robots autonomously navigate based on sensing natural features, with early examples being Pyxus' HelpMate hospital robot and the CyberMotion guard robot, both designed in the 1980s.

## Current Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

I've completed a web search for "human-agent teamwork." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A human-agent team is a system composed of multiple interacting humans and artificial intelligence systems.(no content)The artificial intelligence system may be a robotic system, a decision support system, or a virtual agent.

## Key Characteristics

Human agent teaming provides an interaction paradigm that differs from traditional approaches such as supervisory control, or user interface design, by enabling the computer to have a certain degree of autonomy.(no content)The paradigm draws from various scientific research fields, being strongly inspired by the way humans work together in teams, and constituting a special type of multi-agent system.

## Requirements for Artificial Team Players

For software agents to function effectively as team members, they must meet key requirements:
- Agents must make their status, intentions, knowledge observable to others
- Agents must be predictable to others such that others can rely on them when considering their own actions

## Applications

Human agent teaming is a popular paradigm to approach the interaction between humans and AI technologies in various domains such as defense, healthcare, space, disaster response.

The search results also show related concepts like human-robot collaboration and manned-unmanned teaming, which apply similar principles in specialized contexts.

Here are the search results for "agent simulation environment":

## Overview

Agent-based models are composed of numerous agents at various scales, decision-making heuristics, learning rules or adaptive processes, an interaction topology, and an environment.(no content)ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits.

## Key Concepts

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Applications

Several practical applications exist:

- **Self-Driving Cars**: Waymo created a multi-agent simulation environment called Carcraft to test algorithms for self-driving cars, which simulates traffic interactions between human drivers, pedestrians and automated vehicles.

- **Social Simulations**: Agent-based social simulation (ABSS) consists of social simulations based on agent-based modeling and implemented using artificial agent technologies, concerned with simulation of social phenomena using computer-based multiagent models.

- **Crowd Visualization**: MASSIVE (Multiple Agent Simulation System in Virtual Environment) is a high-end computer animation and artificial intelligence software package used for generating crowd-related visual effects for film and television.

## Environment Properties

Agent environments can be organized according to properties such as accessibility, determinism, dynamics, discreteness, episodicity, and dimensionality.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about intelligent agents in AI:

## Definition

An intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents should react to changes in their environment in a timely way, proactively pursue goals, and be flexible and robust (able to handle unexpected situations). Additionally, intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals.

## Range of Complexity

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Agentic AI

A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.(no content)In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.

## Importance in AI Research

AI textbooks define artificial intelligence as the "study and design of intelligent agents," emphasizing that goal-directed behavior is central to intelligence.

Here's a comprehensive overview of agent framework modeling based on the search results:

## Core Concepts

Agent-Based Modeling (ABM) is more of a modeling framework than a particular piece of software or platform, and it can be applied across multiple domains.

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents. Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Frameworks and Standards

Frameworks have emerged that implement common standards such as FIPA and OMG MASIF standards, with frameworks like JADE saving time and aiding in the standardization of MAS development. JADE (Java Agent Development Framework) is a software framework for the development of software agents, implemented in Java.

## Modern AI Agent Frameworks

With advancements in large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, LLM-based multi-agent frameworks, such as CAMEL, have emerged as a new paradigm for developing multi-agent applications. Frameworks for building AI agents include LangChain, as well as tools such as CAMEL, Microsoft AutoGen, and OpenAI Swarm.

## Applications

Agent-based approaches are used for the development and validation of automated driving systems, with Waymo creating a multi-agent simulation environment Carcraft to test algorithms for self-driving cars that simulates traffic interactions between human drivers, pedestrians and automated vehicles.

I've completed the web search for "space robotics automation." Here's what I found:

## Key Applications of Space Robotics

Space exploration, including Mars rovers, is a major application area for robotics. An early proponent of increased investment in robotic systems published articles and gave congressional testimony on the value of using automation in space long before the successes of NASA's Mars landers, Galileo, and other unmanned space science missions, and also consulted for NASA on the use of robotics in space exploration.

## Modern Space Robotics Technologies

Astrobotic Technology, Inc. is an American private company that is developing space robotics technology for lunar and planetary missions.

Several notable space robots are currently in use:

- **Robonaut**: A humanoid robot developed by the Dexterous Robotics Laboratory at NASA's Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, with the core idea being to have a humanoid machine work alongside astronauts.

- **Telerobotics**: Most space exploration has been conducted with telerobotic space probes.(no content)The robots used in space exploration have been controlled semi-autonomously, with the ability to maneuver itself and be self-sustaining, while always remaining in communications with scientists and engineers on Earth.

These systems represent the intersection of automation, robotics, and space exploration technology.

Links: [{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"List of robotics companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_robotics_companies"},{"title":"Joseph Engelberger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Engelberger"},{"title":"Category:Space robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Space_robots"},{"title":"Industrial robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot"},{"title":"Astrobotic Technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrobotic_Technology"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Robot control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control"},{"title":"Telerobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telerobotics"},{"title":"Robonaut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robonaut"}]

I've completed the web search for "space robotics automation." Here's what I found:

## Key Applications of Space Robotics

Space exploration, including Mars rovers, is a major application area for robotics. An early proponent of increased investment in robotic systems published articles and gave congressional testimony on the value of using automation in space long before the successes of NASA's Mars landers, Galileo, and other unmanned space science missions, and also consulted for NASA on the use of robotics in space exploration.

## Modern Space Robotics Technologies

Astrobotic Technology, Inc. is an American private company that is developing space robotics technology for lunar and planetary missions.

Several notable space robots are currently in use:

- **Robonaut**: A humanoid robot developed by the Dexterous Robotics Laboratory at NASA's Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, with the core idea being to have a humanoid machine work alongside astronauts.

- **Telerobotics**: Most space exploration has been conducted with telerobotic space probes.(no content)The robots used in space exploration have been controlled semi-autonomously, with the ability to maneuver itself and be self-sustaining, while always remaining in communications with scientists and engineers on Earth.

These systems represent the intersection of automation, robotics, and space exploration technology.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've successfully retrieved search results for "Human computer interaction wikipedia". Here's a summary of key information found:

## Definition
The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Purpose and Concept
The term is intended to convey that, unlike other tools with specific and limited uses, computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer.

## Key Disciplines
Human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, drawing from supporting knowledge on both sides. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors are relevant.

## Alternative Names
HCI is also sometimes termed human–machine interaction (HMI), man-machine interaction (MMI) or computer-human interaction (CHI).

## Importance
A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction.

The Wikipedia article covers various aspects of human-computer interaction including different interaction modalities, interface design, and practical applications in modern computing.

I've found several relevant Wikipedia articles on HCI. Here are the main results:

## Primary Article: Human–Computer Interaction

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.(no content)As a field of research, human–computer interaction is situated at the intersection of computer science, behavioral sciences, design, media studies, and several other fields.(no content)The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Related Wikipedia Articles

The search also returned several related topics:

- **Hyper-Converged Infrastructure**: Hyper-converged infrastructure (HCI) is a software-defined IT infrastructure that virtualizes all elements of the conventional "hardware-defined" systems.

- **Feminist HCI**: Feminist HCI is a subfield of human-computer interaction (HCI) that applies feminist theory, critical theory and philosophy to social topics in HCI, including scientific objectivity, ethical values, data collection, data interpretation, reflexivity, and unintended consequences of HCI software.

- **Gender HCI**: Gender HCI is a subfield of human-computer interaction (HCI) that focuses on the design and evaluation of interactive systems for humans, with specific emphasis on variations in how people of different genders interact with computers.
